newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-FORECAST-Burns Philp braces for fall.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-FORECAST-Burns Philp braces for fall.

text.p: Food ingredients group Burns Philp and Co Ltd will confirm next Wednesday that its 1995/96 (June 30) net profit was underdone, the worst result for five years and another disappointment for investors who have watched the stock slump in recent months.

The company, a spices and yeast manufacturer with operations in Australia, the United States, Europe and Asia, said in July that net profit before abnormals would be about 20 percent below the 1994/95 result of A$104.1 million pre-abnormals.
"It will just be another disappointing result, but it is probably reasonably well known in the market already," said one brokerage firm analyst, who forecast A$81.6 million before abmornals.

She said the consumer division in the key United States market, where Burns Philp has fought a price war with the world's number one spices firm McCormick and Co Inc, continued to perform poorly in the fourth quarter.

While the price war is now off the boil, its impact continues to affect the company which has had to pay significant placment, or "slotting" fees, to U.S. supermarkets to ensure that its products caught the consumer's eye.
These payments will be included in an abnormal loss of up to A$100 million for 1995/96 which will also include rationalisation charges and other write-offs.
"I think there is a possibility the abnormals will actually be worse than the A$100 million they have announced," the analyst said, citing this as the only possible surprise next week.

The company may also announce its choice to lead the industrial and food service division next week, the one position still to be filled since the company was restructured from a geographic to a product-based operation in May.

Another analyst, who predicted a 1995/96 net profit of profit about A$80 million, said he had not changed his forecast or sell recommendation on the stock since the company released its surprisingly poor nine month result on May 10.
Burns Philp then revealed that nine month net profit had fallen by 22 percent to A$59.6 million mainly due to the weak U.S. division and that the full year result would fall.
Investors, who had been expecting at least a steady result, began the process of marking the stock down to a 1996 low of A$1.90.
Its year high of A$3.35 was reached at the start of the year when investors and analysts were hoping for an improved result.
The stock was one cent higher at A$2.14 at 11.00 a.m. (0100 gmt) on Friday.
A third analyst said he expected a net profit of A$80 million. "They should start to stabilise next year and probably 1998 is a big year, if they can do it," he said.
